docs.title: Research Software Template
docs.text:
This is the front page of your project. It is more general facing (including for your domain expert) than your repo README. It should provide a high-level overview of your project, its goals and capabilities, and its intended audience.

Write all your documents in Markdown format.

Documents on the site generator used: Material for MkDocs

docs.title: Publishing your docs site
docs.text: GitHub Actions is already setup to build for GitHub Pages. You should enable GitHub Pages in your repository settings and point to the gh-pages branch.

docs.title: Preview your site locally
docs.text:
You need to have Python installed 

# Install the required packages
pip install mkdocs mkdocs-material mkdocs-bibtex
# Start a preview server with live-reloading
mkdocs serve

docs.title: Project structure
docs.text:
.
├── .github/
│   └── workflows/
│       └── gh-pages.yml  # GitHub Actions for building the docs site
├── docs/
│   ├── index.md  # The docs site homepage.
│   ├── user-guide/
│   │   └── ...
│   ├── development/
│   │   └── ...
│   └── references.bib # A BibTeX file for references
├── src/          # Source code for your project
├── test/         # tests files for your project
├── mkdocs.yml    # The docs site configuration file.
└── README.md     # README file for your GitHub repository (not docs site)

To add pages or change the structure of the site, edit the nav: section in the mkdocs.yml file.

docs.title: LaTeX Math expressions
docs.text:
Math Block

$$
\cos x=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^k}{(2k)!}x^{2k}
$$
$$ \cos x=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^k}{(2k)!}x^{2k} $$

Inline Math

$\exists x \in X \forall y \in Y$
Inline Math: \(\exists x \in X \forall y \in Y\)

docs.title: Citations
docs.text:
You can add references to your references.bib file and cite them in your markdown files. For example single citation 1, multiple citations 12. 

(Remove the \ before @)
single citation    [\@SmithAndKoothoor2016]
multiple citations [\@SmithAndKoothoor2016; \@Parnas1978]

  1. W. Spencer Smith and Nirmitha Koothoor. A document-driven method for certifying scientific computing software for use in nuclear safety analysis. Nuclear Engineering and Technology, 48(2):404–418, April 2016. URL: http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1738573315002582, doi:http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.net.2015.11.008. ↩↩

  2. David L. Parnas. Designing software for ease of extension and contraction. In ICSE '78: Proceedings of the 3rd international conference on Software engineering, 264–277. Piscataway, NJ, USA, 1978. IEEE Press. ↩

docs.title: Software Development Documentation
docs.text: This section is intended for the development team, maintainers and end-user developers who aim to extend, modify or adapt the software, or to gain a deeper understanding of the inner workings of this software. This section is not intended for end-users who simply want to use the software as-is.

docs.title: Units of Measurement
docs.text: Symbol Unit Description m meter Length kg kilogram Mass s second Time

docs.title: Symbols
docs.text: Symbol Unit Description \(t\) s time since start of simulation \(\bold{v}\) m/s velocity vector \(\bold{a}\) m/s\(^2\) acceleration vector

docs.title: Abbreviations and Acronyms
docs.text: Symbol Description SRS Software Requirements Specification V&V Verification and Validation IC Initial Conditions

docs.title: Mathematical Notation
docs.text:
In all documents, the following notation is used:

  • Bold font denotes vectors (e.g. \(\bold{v}\))
  • | | denotes the modulus (magnitude) of a vector (e.g. \(|\bold{v}|\))

docs.title: Further Readings
docs.text: Papers, articles, and books that are relevant to the problem and proposed solutions.

docs.title: Unit Test Cases
docs.text: Describe in same way as system test, or link to test files.

docs.title: GitHub
docs.text:
If you run into any bugs or things happen the way you do not expect, the preferred way to reach us is to open an issue in our GitHub repository. Use issues for feature requests as well.

For general questions, discussions, or help, please use GitHub Discussions.

docs.title: Contact Us
docs.text: If you are not comfortable with GitHub, you can also reach us via...
